div1.head: Military Orders regarding Columbia Barracks, June 7, 1900
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
& PINAR DEL RIO.

MILITARY FILE
Recd. JUN 7 - 1900
No. 680

HDQRS. COLUMBIA BARRACKS, CUBA.
JUNE 7TH.1900.

Chief Surgeon's Office.
Hdqrs. Dept. of Havana,
and Pinar Del Rio,
Quemados, Cuba.

Military File,
Rec'd
JUN 7 - 1900
415.

Col. Bks Havana, Cuba.
RECEIVED. JUN 9 Rec'd
COMMANDING OFFICER POST.
Poststamp. LR 1114

States that disinfectants are
needed at his Post and requests
that same be ordered supplied
immediately.
1st Endorsement.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO.
Quemados, Cuba.
To the Chief Surgeon
2nd. Endorsement.

CHIEF SURGEON'S OFFICE.
DEPT. HAVANA & PINAR DEL RIO.
QUEMADOS, CUBA, JUNE 8th, 1900.

Respectfully returned to the Ad-
jutant General, stating that no re-
quisitions for disinfectants have
been recently received from Colum-
bia Barracks. If asked for, disin-
fectants will certainly be supplied
promptly, and to the full measure of
the reasonable needs of the Post.
As to what these needs are, it is
suggested that the Post Surgeon be
consulted, as it is possible that
the post Commander may have heard
complaints from persons not versed
in Sanitary matters who in time of
epidemic often think that good may
be done by the distribution of dis-
infectants on the ground, or the
pouring of them into sewers.

Of this common but particularly
futile form of waste it is possible
that the Surgeon may not approve.

J. R. Kean.
Major & Surgeon, U.S. Vols.,
Chief Surgeon.
3d Endorsement.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF HAVANA
AND PINAR DEL. RIO.
Quemados, Cuba, June 8, 1900.

Respectfully returned to the
Commanding Officer, Columbia Bar-
racks, attention invited to pre-
vious endorsement. Specific re-
port will be submitted in case
dis-infecting material is not
furnished as required.

BY COMMAND OF
BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:

[unclear]
Adjutant General.
JUN -9 Rec'd

June, 10?1900
To Surgeon, For report.

To, be returned as soon as prac-
ticable.
4th Endorsement.

Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks,
Cuba, June 11, 1900.

Respectfully returned to the Ad-
jutant with the information that the
Surgeon has at his command an order
for lime in unlimited quantities, and
this lime will be issued whenever
the occasion for its use arises.

The Surgeon desires in this con-
nection to call attention to the fact
that the routine use of disinfectants
at a post is a reproach upon the san
itary police of the post, and with
a system of sewerage is worse than
useless, for it produces a cessation
of vigilance on the part of those [unclear]
concerned in the sanitary police and
lulls all to a false sense of secu-
rity. Not one ounce of disinfectant
is used at the Hospital, the prefer-
ence being given to perfect clean-
liness. The same result may be at-
tained by all.

Carbolic acid is much inferior to
milk of lime (slaked lime one part,
water eight parts).

The Surgeon begs to state that he
is exercising all due vigilance, and
that he is not a novice in hygienic
measures. The routine issue of dis-
infectants save within the presence of in-
fection is prohibited, and this in-
fection does not exist in this post
at present.(See A. R. 146 E).

A. N. Stark,
Capt & Asst. Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Surgeon.

JUN 11 Recd.
file

div1.head: Letter from T. A. Baldwin to the Adjutant General, June 7, 1900
div1.opener:
HEADQUARTERS COLUMBIA BARRACKS.
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, June 7th, 1900.
To the
Adjutant General,
Dept. of Havana, & Pinar del Rio.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that disinfectants are needed at this
Post, and I am informed by the medical Sanitary Officer that he is un-
able to procure carbolic acid and quick lime.

I would request that the disinfectants be ordered, so that they can
be used liberally at this post.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, T. A. Baldwin Colonel, 7th Cavalry,
Commanding Post
L. S. 417 C.B.C.1900.
J.W.E.
